awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Biomanufactured Platform for Modulating Immune Cell-Bacteria Interactions in the Tumor Microenvironment
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Behkam, Bahareh
Proposal Number: 1454226

Cancer is the second leading cause of death in the U.S., annually claiming over half a million lives. Thus, there is an acute need for improved non-invasive disease diagnostics and more effective drug delivery techniques that minimize toxic side effects. Engineered bacteria have been shown to safely accumulate in tumor tissue with high selectivity and treat cancers that are not responsive to conventional therapies in mouse cancer models. However, clinical success has been rare due to insufficient tumor colonization by bacteria. This is presently attributed to the host immune response, and bacteria-neutrophil interactions in particular have been implicated in several in vivo studies. Nonetheless, interactions of neutrophil and bacteria within the tumor microenvironment remain largely unexplored. This CAREER award focuses on fundamental research in bacteria-neutrophil interactions in a three-dimensional (3D) disease model with the goal of modulating these interactions in order to overcome the immunologic barrier to successful bacteria-based cancer therapy. The proposed CAREER research and education plan has the potential to revolutionize the quality of life by enabling novel cancer treatment pathways, while providing the opportunity to integrate research elements and discoveries into multidisciplinary educational and outreach experiences.

The overarching goal of the research component of this CAREER proposal is to biomanufacture a system based on controlled self-assembly of live, attenuated tumor-targeting bacteria with leukotoxin-loaded nanoparticles in order to enable localized control of bacteria-immune cell interactions within the tumor microenvironment. It is hypothesized that controlling intratumoral inflammation through localized modulation of neutrophil-bacteria interactions will enable bacteria to overcome the immunologic barrier to proliferation in viable tumor tissue. Fundamental studies on cell-cell interactions in engineered 3D disease models will be performed and means for controlling such interactions will be developed.  The following research objectives will be pursued: (1) Biomanufacture and characterize a first-of-its-kind Nanoscale Bacteria Enabled Immune Modulation System (NanoBEIMS) for localized and in-situ disabling of the immunologic barrier to intratumoral proliferation of bacteria; (2) Investigate the role of the mutual effects of bacteria biofilm formation and neutrophil stimulation in intratumoral colonization of bacteria; and (3) Quantify enhancement in bacterial proliferation in tumors caused by NanoBEIMS-enabled localized depletion of neutrophils. The new knowledge gained through this interdisciplinary effort will provide a unique repertoire of enabling technologies for localized cell-cell interaction modulation, as well as highly-targeted theranostic applications for cancer therapy and beyond. Knowledge of the immune system-bacteria interactions is also critical to elucidating the underpinnings of bacterial oncogenesis and enabling effective cancer immunotherapy as well as bacteria-mediated gene therapy. The main goals of the educational component of this CAREER plan are to enhance recruitment and retention of the socioeconomically disadvantaged and ethnically underrepresented groups in STEM and to prepare future scientists to tackle complex multidisciplinary challenges in biotic/abiotic systems engineering (BASE). To this end, this CAREER proposal will establish a multi-tier plan centered on research-inspired learning. The three major components of the plan include: (1) research and training opportunities for elementary school students and teachers from a rural county in southwest Virginia, (2) web-based interactive learning modules to introduce 9-12 year old children to non-traditional areas in engineering at the national level; (3) multidisciplinary research experience for community college students with special focus on underrepresented undergraduates.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Bacteria-based cancer therapy (BBCT) is uniquely advantageous due to its selective growth in primary tumors and metastases, safety, and effectiveness against various solid tumors independent of genetics and resistance to standard molecular therapy. Despite its significant promise, BBCT has not achieved clinical success in solid cancers due to insufficient tumor colonization by bacteria, which has been attributed to the host immune response. Bacteria-neutrophil interactions, in particular, have been implicated in several in vivo studies. In this CAREER award, we conducted fundamental studies on bacteria-host cell interactions in engineered disease models and developed enabling means for controlling such interactions.

Intellectual Merit. Knowledge of the immune cell-bacteria interactions is critical for understanding how bacteria cause cancers and enabling effective cancer immunotherapy and bacteria-mediated gene therapy. The knowledge gained from this research has been foundational to the PI's long-term career goal of developing novel engineered systems for early-stage diagnosis and minimally invasive treatment of cancer, infectious diseases, and cardiovascular disorders.

Broader Impact. The goal of the educational component of this CAREER plan was to enhance recruitment and retention of the socioeconomically disadvantaged and ethnically underrepresented groups in STEM and to prepare future scientists to operate at the interface between engineering and life sciences. This CAREER award was leveraged to establish a multi-tier plan centered on research-inspired learning to provide many opportunities for generating excitement in STEM fields and to teach the multidisciplinary character of modern engineering. Training and professional development opportunities were provided to the PI, 1 postdoctoral scholar, 4 Ph.D. students, 3 M.S. students, and 17 undergraduate and community college students. The PI and 12 of the trainees are from underrepresented groups in Engineering. Findings from this award were widely disseminated through peer-reviewed publications in the form of 2 book chapters, 18 journal papers, 18 conference presentations, and 22 invited seminars. Findings were also shared with over 500 undergraduate and graduate students through classroom teaching. Moreover, educational modules were developed for K-12 students and made available to the public through the institution's outreach platforms, such as the Virginia Tech (VT) College of Engineering Center for the Enhancement of Engineering Diversity and VT Kids Technical University. Scientific discoveries and technological developments enabled by this award have had a significant impact on the principal and other disciplines, a few of which are highlighted below:

1. Development of innovative microfluidic platforms for studying cell-cell interactions and high throughput screening of therapeutics in 3D tissue models. These platform technologies will be beneficial beyond cancer research in drug delivery and infectious disease.

2. Development of a series of metrics to enable quantitative comparison of both the quantity and spatial distribution of therapeutic agents within tissue and an added measure for evaluating the efficacy of new therapeutic compounds in solid tumor therapy. Prior to our work, therapeutic distribution was described by parameters such as volume of distribution, plasma disappearance half-life, and half-life for clearance from the body. These parameters capture overall drug distribution and provide crucial information related to toxicity and effective administration schedule; however, they provide limited information about spatial distribution within tumors. For instance, a therapeutic agent might show an average higher concentration in tumor than in normal tissue (i.e., high volume of distribution), but if tissue penetration is poor, only cells in proximity of the blood vessels will be exposed to effective concentrations. 

3. Development of MEMTrack, an AI-enabled detection and tracking model for studying bacterial motile behavior. MEMTrack provides an unprecedented opportunity for studying bacteria motile behavior in various settings, including infectious diseases, host-microbiome interactions, and microbial ecology.

4. Development of an acoustic microelastopgraphy platform for spatial mapping of tissue stiffness, a well-established physical biomarker, for detecting the onset and progression of various diseases, including cancer.

Improving health care and quality of life is one of the grand challenges of science and engineering. Enhanced targeting of metastatic cancer, delivery of therapeutics to poorly vascularized regions of primary tumors, and development of therapeutics for quiescent cells that are not responsive to conventional chemo and radiotherapies are among the main challenges of cancer treatment. This CAREER award led to the development of a novel biomanufactured system that enables localized weakening of the barriers to BBCT success. 

 


Last Modified: 11/07/2024
Modified by: Bahareh Behkam

  • The biohybrid engineered system consisting of tumor-targeting Salmonella Typhimurium and drug-loaded nanoparticle (left) penetrate in tumor models (right) to induce anti-tumor effects.
